description: From Middle English crenclen (“to bend, buckle”), from Old English *crinclian, frequentative form of Old English crincan (“to yield”), from Proto-Germanic *kringaną (“to turn, to fall, to yield”), from Proto-Indo-European *ger- (“to turn, wind”). Cognate with North Frisian krenge, krönge (“to obtain, reach, attain”), Dutch krinkelen (“to turn, wind”). Related to cringe.

entries.meaning: A wrinkle, fold, crease, or unevenness.
examples: He observed the crinkles forming around his eyes and suddenly felt old.

verbs.description: crinkle (third-person singular simple present crinkles, present participle crinkling, simple past and past participle crinkled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To fold, crease, crumple, or wad.
examples: He crinkled the wrapper and threw it out.
The old man's lined face crinkled into a smile.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rustle, as stiff cloth when moved.
examples: The green wheat crinkles like a lake.
